elements.title: a statue of the Medicine Buddha (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that a statue of the Medicine Buddha (pictured), dating from the late 8th or early 9th century, never left its temple grounds until 2024?

elements.title: Pavel Kushnir (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Russian pianist Pavel Kushnir died on a hunger strike after his arrest for anti-war videos posted on a YouTube channel with five subscribers?

elements.title: human history (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that public health measures and advances in medical science in modern human history helped raise global life expectancy from about 31 years in 1900 to over 66 years in 2000?

elements.title: Wake Me Up When September Ends (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Green Day's "Wake Me Up When September Ends" became closely associated with the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina?

elements.title: Liebigs Annalen (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that scientists publishing in Liebigs Annalen were subject to criticism and attacks by editor Justus von Liebig?

elements.title: Charlotte Eyton (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that English amateur geologist Charlotte Eyton wrote a number of papers and pamphlets on the geology of the Wrekin, a part of Shropshire, between 1862 and 1870?

elements.title: he found weights in their winning fish two years ago today (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the director of a Lake Erie-based walleye fishing tournament defended two anglers accused of cheating until he found weights in their winning fish two years ago today?

elements.title: East Suffolk Park (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that East Suffolk Park, a former student hostel in Edinburgh, was once an internment camp for enemy aliens?

elements.title: Kyle Hergel (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that football player Kyle Hergel said his biggest strength was "my nastiness"?
